newsitem.title: USA: Stocks gain in quiet market.
newsitem.headline: Stocks gain in quiet market.

text.p: Wall Street stocks were slightly higher Wednesday in a sluggish session that saw much of the activity limited to a few individual issues.

At 1:00 p.m. EDT, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.48 points at 5,712.75. In the broader market, advancing issues led declines by a 11-9 on moderate volume of 177 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite index was up 2.93 to 1,151.95 and the American Stock Exchange index rose 0.78 to 562.83.
Except for a few standout performers, blue chips were generally steady, paced by a subdued bond market ahead of Wednesdasy afternoon's Treasury auction of $12.5 billion in five-year notes.
"The market continues to wallow and is basically directionless," said Dick Stein, vice president at U.S. Clearing Corp. "I think everyone is looking forward to the long weekend."
Treasuries were generally steady, defying predictions that a sell-off would push yields up ahead of Wednesday's Treasury sale.
Analysts had expressed concern about demand for the notes after participation levels for Tuesday's two-year note auction proved disappointing.
In the bond market, the 30-year Treasury slipped 1/32, or 31 cents on a $1,000 bond, raising its yield to 6.98 percent from 6.97 percent at Tuesday's close.

Among individual issues, CompuServe Corp. rose 1-1/16 to 13-3/8 after H&R Block Inc., which holds a major shareholder, called off a proposal to spin off its 80 percent stake in the online service provider.

H&R Block, which cited projected losses at CompuServe and online industry market uncertainties as reasons for the decision, fell 1-5/8 to 26-1/4. H&R Block said it will continue to consider a future spin-off of CompuServe.
Reebok International Ltd. rose 15/16 to 35-1/2 after saying that it would buy back 17 million shares at $36 a share under a previously announced repurchase.

Garden Botanika Inc. slid 3-7/16 to 9-13/16 after it reported a loss for the latest quarter. The company also said its August sales were disappointing and could bode ill for its third-quarter results.
